article_title: LIVE Blog: GOP Presidential hopefuls outline vision
article_text:
Is there risk here? Duprey cracked, "I don't think anyone will make a fatal error here, unless they endorse Hillary Clinton."

(Nineteen potential or declared Republican presidential hopefuls are speaking to the "First in the Nation" GOP summit in Nashua Friday and Saturday. Check back for updates.)Summit stories include:- - - - -wrapped up his remarks by repeating his call for across-the-board tax cuts to help stimulate the economy. He began his address to the #FITN audience with a joke about how he worried he would arrive late, because he was busy going through his emails and seeing which ones to delete -- another email deletion joke directed at former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. Gilmore kept his ire focused on President Obama, however. "Obamacare is a problem, ladies and gentlemen. No. 1, because it forces people to buy something that they don't want."- - - - -, who is still considering a run, emphasized his executive experience as former governor of Texas. He strike a tone as a Washington outsider, but pointed to the GOP majority on Capitol Hill. "A congressional majority is a terrible thing to waste," he said.Perry said the U.S. should provide that more domestic policy is handled by the states, and not the federal government. He was also critical of the Common Core curriculum standards."Common Core is every bit as problematic as Obamacare," he said.an entrepreneur and film producer running for President, is speaking now. Former Texas Gov. Rick Perry is scheduled to give noon remarks, followed by former Virginia Gov. Jim Gilmore.Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz pushed back against the GOP criticism during a news conference in Nashua."We do not have a presumptive nominee. We will have a primary. I expect it to be competitive. We will have a discussion of ideas on our side of the aisle as well.New Hampshire Democratic Party Chairman Ray Buckley joined Wasserman Schultz in criticizing the Republican hopefuls. "We find these summits very helpful to us," said Buckley, maintaining the more exposure GOP candidates receive, the more likely they will be rejected.- Kim Houghton- - - - -ormer New York Gov. George Pataki learn from 9/11? Pataki, in a question-and-answer format he designed to appear before the #FITN summit, said he learned that Islamic terrorism is real and he said he learned the strength of America. Pataki spoke about the need to reduce the size and scope of the federal government, repeal the Affordable Care Act, and "reclaim" the 10th Amendment, what has become a common comment lately among Republicans who say some domestic policies should be left up to the states.Pataki said the Republican nominee would beat Hillary Clinton.In a media briefing after his remarks, Pataki was asked about being in the lower tier of possible GOP hopefuls. "It's not where you start, it's where you finish," he said.to gain the most?The summit, with 500-600 attendees each day, offers a real opportunity for some of the lesser-known presidential hopefuls, said RNC member Steve Duprey, wearing a "Straight Talk Express" jacket from John McCain's campaign in 2008.Likely candidates like former New York Gov. George Pataki and U.S. Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-SC."Every candidate who runs in New Hampshire is going to be tested," Duprey said.- - - - - -opened the "First in the Nation" primary summit here Friday morning by urging activists to focus on winning back the White House in 2016."My friends, it is time for a change," Horn said in opening remarks at the Crowne Plaza. "It is time for a renewed american spirit for a return to an America of growth and prosperity, an America of freedom, security and principled leadership. The change starts right here, right now, with everyone of you. You have the power to start our nation back on the right path. This is going to be an excited, engaging primary and I encourage you to embrace your role in it. Ask the tough questions, demand forthright answers. Get involved. Choose your favorite candidate and work as hard as you know how to work to get your favorite Republican elected.""But I'm telling you right now, please, please, save your attacks for the Democrats."Horn said Republicans have the "most-diverse, most-qualified slate" of presidential hopefuls in her lifetime. She zinged Democrats for falling in step behind Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton.DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz is holding a news conference nearby the hotel here in Nashua to criticize Republican hopefuls.- - - -attendees take in the size of the event;"The Republicans and Democrats really value the primary," said Jim McConaha, a Republican from Concord. "This is really a proclamation of that as much as anything else."McConaha recalled that when he first moved to New Hampshire, back in 1972, he one day saw presidential candidates walking the streets of Manchester. It was an introduction into New Hampshire as home to the country's first presidential primary.Tammy Simmons, a Republican state representative from Manchester, who is operations director in New Hampshire for presidential hopeful Rand Paul, said she thinks the #FITN primary summit will become a regular event.Ed Stebbins, a volunteer from Nashua, notes that some friends in greater Nashua inquired about attending, but that the event is sold out. He is also looking to learn more about the presidential hopefuls -- nearly every Republican running for the White House will be speaking here either Friday or Saturday."I'm looking for someone with executive experience," Stebbins said.- - - -Jane Cormier of Hooksett was here early at the Crowne Plaza in Nashua for the "#FITN Republican Leadership Summit." She says she is here to "stick her nose into it," and convey information to neighbors and friends who are interested in the presidential hopefuls. Cormier, with New Hampshire Right to Life, has already made up her mind. U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, is her candidate."I've been watching him for two years," Cormier said. "I was on before anyone was watching."Why Cruz? She said she likes his principles, and sees him as a genuine constitutional conservative. With other candidates, you often hear rhetoric, she said."The lips don't tell the story. The votes tell the story," Cruz said.- - - -dtuohy@unionleader.com and khoughton@newstote.comFollow on Twitter: @tuohy

article_metadata.description: NASHUA – State Republican Party Chairwoman Jennifer Horn opened the 'First in the Nation' primary summit here Friday morning by urging activists to focus on winning back the White House in 2016.
article_metadata.title: LIVE Blog: GOP Presidential hopefuls outline vision | New Hampshire
